thesis.description: Polyphrase est un agencement de phrases (ou théorèmes) obtenues au moyen de démonstrations permises par un système combinatoire. Le choix des schémas de production du système est effectué de telle sorte que les phrases obtenues soient des expressions s'a eu près 12 variables séparées par des opérateurs. Les variables reçoivent des interprétations musicales, et les opérateurs définissent des relations temporelles entre variables: juxtaposition, tuilage, simultanéité, etc. Au niveau supérieur, une première phrase définit toute la pièce, englobant les deux mouvements. Ensuite toutes les variables de cette phrase deviennent axiomes de nouvelles démonstrations aboutissant à autant de phrases de niveau inférieur. On arrive finalement à un ensemble d'expressions du type défini, séparées elles aussi par des opérateurs: Polyphrase, ou Phrase de phrases. A mesure que l'on chemine du premier axiome vers le niveau inférieur, les variables sont interprétées avec une précision croissante, afin que les phrases inferieures définissent adéquatement la musique à faire entendre: types évènements sonores et leurs relations dans le temps.

Polyphrase is an arrangement of phrases (or theorems) obtained through demonstartions allowed by a combinatorial system. The production rules of the system are chosen so that the resulting phrases be expressions of approximately 12 variables separated by operators. The variables bear musical interpretations, and teh operators define temporal relations among variables: juxtapostition, overlapping, simultaneity, etc. At the upper level, a first phrase defines the whole piece, comprising both moevements. Then all the variables of this phrase become axioms of new demonstrations leading to as many lower level phrases. We finally arrive at a set of expressions fo the defined type, which are also separated by the operators: Polyphrase, or phrase of phrases. On the way from the first axiom to the lowere level, the variables are interpreted with increasing precision so that the lower phrases appropriately define the music to ebheard: types of musical events and their relations in time.

thesis.subject: Orchestral music.
thesis.title: Polyphrase pour orchestre.

thesis.description: This thesis analyses the development of Yeats's image of Japan from his introduction to Japanese culture through 'Japonisme' in the mid-1880's, until the end of his life in 1939. It also surveys the sources of information that Yeats had on Japan other than the Noh drama, and shows how these sources were as important as the Noh, if not more, in defining his image of Japan as an artistic utopia. Three periods of Japanese history were of particular interest to Yeats: The early nineteenth century, in which most Japanese colour prints were produced; the Ashikaga period (1333-1573), when the Noh flourished, and Heian Japan (794-1100), an extraordinary culture which produced some of the world's greatest works of art. Images of Japanese culture from these periods combined to produce a composite, mythical vision of Japan in Yeats's imagination.
